    <item>
      <title>May's Brexit transition demand 'would penalise EU citizens'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/theresa-may-brexit-transition-demand-demonise-eu-citizens-verhofstadt</link>
      <description><p>Unthinkable for EU to agree to PM’s key demand on citizens’ rights, says Verhofstadt</p><p>Theresa May’s demand that EU nationals coming to the UK during a Brexit transition deal should enjoy fewer rights than those already in the country would amount to “penalising citizens”, Guy Verhofstadt has said.</p><p>Verhofstadt, the European parliament’s Brexit coordinator, said May was “not very serious” when she proposed the idea.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/theresa-may-brexit-transition-demand-demonise-eu-citizens-verhofstadt">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Cutting tuition fees would backfire, Justine Greening warns PM</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/18/cutting-tuition-fees-would-backfire-justine-greening-warns-theresa-may</link>
      <description><p>Ex-education secretary says reducing fees for some courses would harm social mobility</p><p>The government’s desire to cut tuition fees for students on courses with lower graduate earnings is fraught with difficulty and unlikely to succeed, the former education secretary Justine Greening has warned.</p><p>Speaking ahead of Theresa May’s announcement on Monday of a major review of higher education funding, Greening outlined her concern that forcing fees lower in such circumstances would backfire and harm social mobility.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/18/cutting-tuition-fees-would-backfire-justine-greening-warns-theresa-may">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>London’s Labour leaders in new row over Walthamstow regeneration plans</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/17/waltham-forest-regeneration-stella-creasy-coghill-private-finance</link>
      <description><p>Council leader and local MP Stella Creasy under fire over housing proposals where just 20% of homes will be ‘affordable’</p><p>A new controversy over the use of public-private housing schemes has erupted in one of Labour’s north London strongholds, closely mirroring the row in neighbouring Haringey that resulted in <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jan/30/labour-council-leader-to-quit-due-to-sexism-and-bullying" title="">the resignation last month</a> of the party’s most senior woman in local government.</p><p>Divisions over a flagship regeneration scheme in Walthamstow – now a magnet for younger middle-class homebuyers – led to its council leader rebuking shadow chancellor John McDonnell after he publicly suggested that the development plans should be dropped.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/17/waltham-forest-regeneration-stella-creasy-coghill-private-finance">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Neil Kinnock warns Jeremy Corbyn: ‘Stop Brexit to save the NHS’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/neil-kinnock-jeremy-corbyn-labour-stop-brexit-save-nhs</link>
      <description>As 20,000 Labour members protest at party stance on Brexit, former leader adds pressure to resist leaving EU<p>Jeremy Corbyn has come under intense pressure to shift Labour’s position on Brexit after 20,000 members demanded a say over the issue and former leader Neil Kinnock backed halting Britain’s EU exit altogether.</p><p>It is understood that the Labour leader will also be confronted by some in his shadow cabinet this week who want him to back remaining in the single market and customs union.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/neil-kinnock-jeremy-corbyn-labour-stop-brexit-save-nhs">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>MPs’ ‘fake news’ inquiry barred from UK embassy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/mps-fake-news-inquiry-barred-uk-washington-embassy-donald-trump</link>
      <description>Diplomats said ‘offending Trump’ was reason for decision not to host historic session in Washington<p>The British embassy in Washington backtracked on promises to host a session of the parliamentary inquiry into fake news, because of worries it might offend Donald Trump, the <em>Observer</em> has learned.</p><p>Barely a week before MPs from the digital, culture, media and sport committee were due to arrive in Washington for the historic session on 8 February, they were informed in a letter from foreign office minister Alan Duncan that they would have to find a new venue. “We had a report back ... that either the embassy or the UK government felt this would be unhelpful because of the relationship with the US government,” said Ian Lucas, one of the committee members.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/mps-fake-news-inquiry-barred-uk-washington-embassy-donald-trump">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ukip members oust Henry Bolton as leader after only five months</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-members-oust-henry-bolton-as-leader-after-five-months</link>
      <description>Crisis-hit party chooses figure who said Islam is ‘death cult’ as new leader<p>Members of Ukip voted yesterday to sack Henry Bolton, who had been elected only last September as the crisis-hit party’s fourth leader in 18 months. Bolton had been clinging on to the leadership despite a revolt by senior figures after the press reported his relationship with Jo Marney, a model who sent offensive messages about Meghan Markle, the fiancee of Prince Harry.</p><p>Bolton was ousted on Saturday at an emergency meeting where an overwhelming majority of party members endorsed a motion of no confidence in his leadership passed by the party’s ruling national executive committee (NEC). Activists at the meeting in Birmingham <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/ukip-members-vote-to-sack-leader-henry-bolton">voted by 867 to 500</a> in favour of a no-confidence motion on his ability to lead Ukip.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-members-oust-henry-bolton-as-leader-after-five-months">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Theresa May wants new security treaty with EU next year</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/theresa-may-wants-new-security-treaty-with-eu-next-year</link>
      <description><p>British PM seeks treaty on post-Brexit military, intelligence and counter-terrorism cooperation</p><p>Theresa May wants to leave the EU’s common foreign and security policy as early as next year, but would show flexibility around the UK’s red lines to secure a new security treaty.</p><p>“There is no reason why we should not agree distinct agreements for our foreign and defence policy cooperation in the time-limited implementation period”, the British prime minister told European and US officials at the Munich security conference on Saturday. “The key aspects of our future partnership in this area will already be effective from 2019.<br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/theresa-may-wants-new-security-treaty-with-eu-next-year">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Northern Ireland secretary says power-sharing deal still possible</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/16/northern-ireland-secretary-says-power-sharing-deal-still-possible</link>
      <description><p>Karen Bradley pledges to ‘do all I can’ to get talks between DUP and Sinn Féin back on track</p><p>The UK government still believes a deal can be done between Sinn Féin and the Democratic Unionist party aimed at restoring power-sharing to Stormont, the Northern Ireland secretary has said.</p><p>Karen Bradley insisted she and her colleagues in the Irish government wanted to get the talks between the two main parties represented in the deadlocked Northern Ireland assembly back on track.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/16/northern-ireland-secretary-says-power-sharing-deal-still-possible">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Angela Merkel 'curious' about UK's Brexit plan, but not 'frustrated'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/16/angela-merkel-curious-about-uks-brexit-plan-but-not-frustrated</link>
      <description><p>German leader conciliatory as Theresa May prepares to outline her security ideas in Munich</p><p>Angela Merkel told Theresa May on Friday that she was “curious” about, but “not frustrated” with the British government’s slow progress in outlining its vision of the future relationship with the European Union.</p><p>Speaking in conciliatory terms as Britain’s prime minister prepares to present her ideas on security cooperation in Munich on Saturday, the German chancellor said that the two sides were seeking common ground. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/16/angela-merkel-curious-about-uks-brexit-plan-but-not-frustrated">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Oxfam government funding cut off after Haiti scandal</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/16/oxfam-government-funding-cut-off-after-haiti-scandal</link>
      <description><p>Charity agrees to demand from development department to stop bidding for grants until ‘high standards’ met<br></p><p>Oxfam has agreed to withdraw from bidding for government funding until the Department for International Development is satisfied that it can meet the “high standards” expected.</p><p>In a statement, the international development secretary, Penny Mordaunt, said she had made a set of demands <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/16/oxfam-chief-accuses-critics-of-gunning-for-charity-over-haiti-sex-scandal-claims">in light of the sexual exploitation scandal in Haiti </a>and had received a formal response from Oxfam agreeing to them. She said that the government “reserves the right to take whatever decisions about present or future funding to Oxfam, and any other organisation, that we deem necessary”. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/16/oxfam-government-funding-cut-off-after-haiti-scandal">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Unbalanced Britain needs more devolution to manage Brexit</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/18/unbalanced-britain-more-devolution-manage-brexit</link>
      <description><p>With woeful productivity in parts, local authorities should decide how to spend the cash that replaces EU funds</p><p>Throughout the 1980s, a war raged between Westminster and the rest of the country that has had lasting effects. Fearing councils under the control of Michael Foot’s Labour opposition, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/local-government-network/2013/apr/09/local-government-margaret-thatcher-war-politics">Margaret Thatcher stripped power from town halls in a sweeping political land grab</a> that still marks Britain today.</p><p><a href="http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/politicsandpolicy/britains-spatially-unbalanced-economy/">London’s economy during the 1970s and much of the 1980s had more in common with the rest of the country</a> than today. It even grew at a slower pace than many other regions, but the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/oct/09/big-bang-1986-city-deregulation-boom-bust">big bang deregulation of financial services</a> in 1986 under Nigel Lawson, then chancellor, helped London’s economy to boom — aided by fat profits from investment banks in the City. At the same time, the north’s industrial base came under attack from Thatcher’s reforms, since when manufacturing as a share of national income has fallen <a href="http://cep.lse.ac.uk/pubs/download/cp414.pdf">from a quarter to just over 10%</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/18/unbalanced-britain-more-devolution-manage-brexit">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>You’ve heard about the north-south divide. How about the west-east one? | Will Hutton</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/youve-heard-about-north-south-divide-how-about-west-east-one</link>
      <description>Geographical inequalities are the result of historical legacies and a fractured economy<p>Place has always been destiny in Britain, but never more so than in 2018. Pity the child born in Weymouth, Corby or Carlisle, locked into poor schools, a lacklustre economy and few decent jobs; if he or she had been lucky enough to be born in Tower Hamlets, Hackney or Westminster, their <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/inequality/2017/nov/28/social-mobility-stark-postcode-lottery-too-many-britain-left-behind-alan-milburn-commission-report" title="">life chances</a> might have been transformed. Where you are born in Britain, and England in particular, is becoming ever more a treacherous geographical lottery.</p><p>Nor is the divide any more just the well-known one between north and south. So relatively strong are the performances of Bristol and Manchester, with Liverpool hard on their heels, that overlaid on the old north-south split is the beginnings of a new one – an east-west divide. Parts of the north-west such as Trafford and North Cheshire are strong economic and social performers, while the towns along the M4 and Bristol itself are doing pretty well.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/youve-heard-about-north-south-divide-how-about-west-east-one">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Scottish nationalists are salivating over the Brexit spoils | Kevin McKenna</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/scottish-nationalists-salivating-over-brexit-spoils</link>
      <description>The only question for the SNP is how long to wait before calling a new vote on independence<p>Like a drunk man leaving the dance floor, the UK’s slow, anarchic exit from the EU continues and the Scottish nationalists can scarce believe the abundance of fresh opportunities that have landed at their feet. Their biggest task now is to decide how to deploy them and when?</p><p>More than three years after the first referendum on Scottish independence, the 45% who voted to leave the UK have never wavered, with polls consistently showing a slight increase. On its own, this ought to concern unionists. They had convinced themselves that a Tory resurgence in Scotland had occurred under Ruth Davidson’s energetic leadership and that this had finally put independence beyond the reach of the nationalists for the time being. However, the “resurgence” had been built on sand. The new intake of Scottish Tory MPs and local councillors began to resemble a 19th-century freak-show accompanied by an unlovely symphony of flutes and banjos; accordingly, they have since assumed their normal third place in the polls.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/scottish-nationalists-salivating-over-brexit-spoils">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>If paying for sex is wrong in Haiti, why do we still tolerate it in the UK? | Catherine Bennett</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/if-paying-for-sex-wrong-in-haiti-why-do-we-tolerate-it-in-uk</link>
      <description>Amid anger at Oxfam, where are the voices of those who turn a blind eye to exploited  women at home?<p>Finally, something on which we can agree: charity officials ought not to buy sex. No one, so far, seems prominently to have argued, of the Oxfam employees’ misconduct in Haiti and Liberia, that, providing their female purchases were adult, and not coerced, then their prostitution should rightly be called sex work, that is: a perfectly dignified transaction, from which both sides – say, impoverished survivors of a disaster and benevolent male humanitarians – stood to benefit.</p><p>We have yet, admittedly, to hear from Amnesty International, the human rights NGO, which now doubles as the world’s leading advocate of legalised prostitution. In 2015, a year that will forever be celebrated by its allies in the pimping and trafficking community, Amnesty committed to the decriminalisation of all aspects of “sex work that does not involve coercion, exploitation or abuse”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/if-paying-for-sex-wrong-in-haiti-why-do-we-tolerate-it-in-uk">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Labour will win the next election if it becomes the party of Remain | Eloise Todd</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/labour-win-election-party-of-remain-brexit</link>
      <description><p>Only a tiny proportion of the party’s voters last year strongly wanted to leave the EU – opposing a disastrous Brexit will shake up the electoral map</p><p>Recently, there has been story after story about Brexit ministers giving speeches laying out a road map. This is apart from the chancellor, who has been sent to the Arctic. While the focus for this last week might have been on the Conservative government and its road to nowhere, soon the pendulum will swing back towards the Labour party and its position on Brexit.</p><p>Labour fought the election on a mandate that has been hailed as a brilliant middle way between Remain and Leave. MPs on the frontbench Brexit team want to find a solution “somewhere between in and out”. But there is a decision still facing our country and it doesn’t involve a middle way.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/labour-win-election-party-of-remain-brexit">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Labour is dreaming if it believes Britain wants socialism</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/labour-dreaming-uk-wants-socialism-privatisation</link>
      <description>The government might be in disarray but anxious over-50s, keen to protect their wealth and savings, have still got its back<p>At this stage of the Brexit talks there seem to be few barriers to the Tory party dominating the outcome. It’s not the string of opinion polls showing Theresa May either ahead, neck and neck or only marginally behind Labour, all of which are stunningly positive survey results for a government in such&nbsp;disarray.</p><p>Nor is it the way <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/13/boris-johnson-warns-thwarting-brexit-vote-would-be-disastrous" title="">Boris Johnson</a> and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/06/anna-soubry-urges-may-to-sling-out-arch-brexiters" title="">Anna Soubry</a> slug it out with passion and alternative visions of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/10/brexit-theresa-may-problems-to-resolve-end-of-year-tory-leadership" title="">Brexit</a>, while Labour MPs merely lament the referendum result, stymied by a leadership that has so far preferred to play tactical games rather than put forward its preferred post-Brexit relationships.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/labour-dreaming-uk-wants-socialism-privatisation">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Like many officers, I do not want a two-tier system. Everyone deserves a good service – not just those who can afford it<br></p><p>A meet and greet service from your car or nearest Tube station.     <item>
      <title>The language we use in public and on social media has repercussions. The first step must greater civility | James Graham</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/17/language-public-social-media-politics-repercussions</link>
      <description><p>The language we use in public and on social media has repercussions. The first step must greater civility</p><p>When the general atmosphere is bad, language must suffer,” George Orwell said in 1946. As then, so now – but worse. I know, everyone’s always saying things are worse. Let’s not hark back to an age that never existed. But it is time to recognise the conversation crisis in public and civic life.</p><p>I don’t quite believe, like some, that the Enlightenment values of tolerance and civilised debate are being reversed; but they are certainly under threat. This age of unreason we’re living through is defined not only by “<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/political-science/2016/nov/01/why-michael-gove-is-right-to-challenge-experts-to-raise-their-game" title="">had enough of experts</a>”, but with normally reasonable people – you and I – behaving wilfully unreasonably to one another. And by the fact civility itself is now regarded as an obstacle to change, where once it was its best hope.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/17/language-public-social-media-politics-repercussions">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The key pitfalls on the road to Brexit</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/14/the-key-pitfalls-on-the-road-to-brexit</link>
      <description><p>The road to Brexit was never going to be easy. Here’s a guide to the trickiest obstacles...</p><p><strong>Lords revolt<br></strong><em>February</em></p><p>The committee stage of the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/eu">European Union</a> withdrawal bill begins in the House of Lords later this month. Ten days have been allocated for what will be fiery debates. Cross-party groups of peers will vote on a range of amendments that could torpedo the prime minister’s plans for Brexit.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/14/the-key-pitfalls-on-the-road-to-brexit">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/eu-referendum">Brexit</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/article-50">Article 50</category>

      <title>Brendan Cox resigns from charities amid sexual assault claims</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/brendan-cox-resigns-from-charities-amid-sexual-assault-claims</link>
      <description><p>Husband of murdered MP denies allegations but admits ‘mistakes’ while at Save the Children</p><p>The husband of the murdered MP Jo Cox has resigned from the two charities he set up in her memory after being publicly accused of sexual assault. </p><p>Brendan Cox has stepped down from his posts at <a href="http://www.moreincommon.com/">More in Common</a> and the <a href="https://www.jocoxfoundation.org/">Jo Cox Foundation</a> after allegations, printed in the Mail on Sunday, that he had assaulted a woman in her 30s at Harvard University in 2015. Police filed her complaint as assault and battery but action against him was dropped. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/brendan-cox-resigns-from-charities-amid-sexual-assault-claims">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ukip's Gerard Batten reiterates his belief that Islam is a 'death cult'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-gerard-batten-islam-muslims-quran</link>
      <description><p>Interim leader says Muslims should sign a document renouncing parts of the Qur’an</p><p>Ukip’s interim leader, Gerard Batten, has reiterated his belief that Islam is a “death cult” and called for Muslims to be asked to sign a document renouncing parts of the Qur’an, in remarks that risk pushing the beleaguered party even further from the mainstream.</p><p>Batten, an MEP for London, took over as party head on Saturday after <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-members-oust-henry-bolton-as-leader-after-five-months">Henry Bolton was removed</a> at an emergency general meeting of party members, called when Bolton refused to step down following controversy about his personal affairs.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-gerard-batten-islam-muslims-quran">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Revealed:  rightwing groups plot to ditch EU safety standards on food and drugs</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/revealed-us-uk-rightwing-thinktanks-talks-to-ditch-eu-safety-checks</link>
      <description>‘Ideal’ UK-US trade deal would see banned products sold in post-Brexit Britain, says accidentally released memo<p>An unprecedented drive to lobby ministers to ditch strict EU safety standards in order to secure a US trade deal is being drawn up by a transatlantic group of conservative thinktanks, it has emerged.</p><p>Organisers of the self-styled “shadow trade talks”, which are set to include 10 leading rightwing and libertarian groups from the UK and the US, are preparing to push their “ideal free trade agreement” that would allow the import of US meats, drugs and chemicals banned in Britain.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/revealed-us-uk-rightwing-thinktanks-talks-to-ditch-eu-safety-checks">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Netherlands plans to boost customs staff by 750 as reality of Britain’s EU departure sinks in</p><p>The Dutch government plans to hire at least 750 new customs agents in preparation for Britain’s exit from the European Union.<br></p><p>The Dutch parliament’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/eu-referendum">Brexit</a> rapporteur, Pieter Omtzigt, who had recommended the move, said both sides of the English Channel had been slow to wake up to the reality that Britain was on course to leave the EU in 14 months’ time.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/brexit-uk-thousands-customs-netherlands">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Theresa May to warn EU not to put ideology before citizens' safety</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/16/theresa-may-to-warn-eu-not-to-let-ideology-put-its-citizens-at-risk</link>
      <description><p>PM to propose new UK-EU security treaty to close gaps that terrorists could exploit</p><p>The EU could put its citizens at risk if it allows ideology or rigid institutions to blind its leaders to the need to cooperate against terror threats, Theresa May will say on Saturday, proposing a new UK-EU treaty on intelligence and security.</p><p>The prime minister risks a rift with Europe in a speech in which she will say the UK wants to stay closely aligned with Europe on security policy, but that “rigid institutional restrictions” or “deep-seated ideology” could leave gaps that terrorists and organised criminals may seek to exploit. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/16/theresa-may-to-warn-eu-not-to-let-ideology-put-its-citizens-at-risk">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/15/labour-gets-16000-emails-in-five-days-urging-it-to-consult-on-brexit</link>
      <description><p>Shadow cabinet and trade unions to discuss after complaints that none of party’s policy commissions focus on Europe</p><p>More than 16,000 people have emailed Labour over the past five days, urging the party to consult members on Brexit after MPs said the topic was being ignored by its most senior policy body.</p><p>The emails from party members will be examined by the party’s national policy forum (NPF), which meets this weekend in Leeds, and whose members include the shadow cabinet and trade union leaders.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/15/labour-gets-16000-emails-in-five-days-urging-it-to-consult-on-brexit">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Nigel Farage withdraws 'violent means' claim against Hope Not Hate</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/nov/14/nigel-farage-withdraws-claim-hope-not-hate-high-court</link>
      <description><p>Former Ukip leader retracts assertion made about anti-extremist group last December after crowdfunded libel action</p><p>Nigel Farage has formally withdrawn his claim that Hope Not Hate pursues “violent and undemocratic means” after it launched a crowdfunded libel case against the former Ukip leader.<br></p><p>The anti-extremism pressure group said on Tuesday that Farage had filed a statement with the high court in London saying he was “happy to acknowledge that Hope Not Hate does not tolerate or pursue violent or undemocratic behaviour” and that he would not repeat the claim.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/nov/14/nigel-farage-withdraws-claim-hope-not-hate-high-court">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Boris digs himself deeper as his usual tricks fall flat | John Crace</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/14/boris-digs-himself-deeper-as-his-usual-tricks-fall-flat</link>
      <description><p>The foreign secretary had no hard facts to back up his Brexit vision, just a few lame tropes</p><p>It was the pathos rather than the hypocrisy that really struck home. The entertainer who used to sell out the O2 and now can’t even buy a gig as a warm-up act in front of a captive afternoon audience of retirement home residents. Boris Johnson tried all his familiar tricks. He smirked. He trotted out some bad gags. He spoke a bit of Latin. He went off on predictable riffs. </p><p> All things that had worked so well for him in the past but now fell completely flat. He was a man with only his own narcissism for company. And there’s no lonelier place than that. He coulda been a contender. He coulda been someone. Instead of the bum he now is.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/14/boris-digs-himself-deeper-as-his-usual-tricks-fall-flat">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ukip leader Henry Bolton arrives at crucial party meeting</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/ukip-leader-henry-bolton-arrives-at-crucial-party-meeting</link>
      <description><p>Fate of leader hangs in balance as activists prepare to vote on whether to endorse motion of no confidence in his leadership </p><p>The Ukip leader, Henry Bolton, has arrived at a make-or-break meeting that will decide his political future.</p><p>About 2,000 activists at an emergency meeting in Birmingham will vote on whether to endorse a motion of no confidence in his leadership passed by the party’s ruling national executive committee (NEC).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/ukip-leader-henry-bolton-arrives-at-crucial-party-meeting">Continue reading...</a></description>
